In the Maldives, national assessments indicate poor learning achievements in students, with major disparities between the capital city and other islands of the Maldives. The Maldives face challenges related to training and further development of teachers' skills. UNICEF Maldives is piloting an e-learning platform based on open source Moodle platform to deliver large volumes of content to educators across the country. The development of the platform is currently being finalized based on user feedback that indicate teachers to be open to e-learning tools. Course content is being developed with the National Institute of Education. The platform is expected to go live in July 2017.

When this e-learning platform is established, it will reach approximately 4,000 teachers across 200 islands, serving 220 schools. This will be translated into enhanced quality of teaching, which will lead to better learning outcomes in students.

UNICEF Uganda has been supporting the development and deployment of U-Portal, a digital content management tool, in schools and youth centres. The existing Drupal-based backend to Kolibri, developed by the Foundation for Learning Equality, has been upgraded during this project. The Learning Management System and Learning App are designed to run on low-power devices, targeting the needs of learners and teachers in contexts with limited infrastructure. A user can install Kolibri and use the app on a local network without Internet connection, as well as create and share content with others.
 
User testing was done in Uganda among 14-16 year old school children to test the functionalities of the platform. Over 100 pieces of digital  content have been curated to match the Ugandan school curriculum. Kolibri will be piloted initially in 10 schools from February 2017 onwards, and rolled out to 100+ schools from May 2017 onwards with support from UNICEF.

The real-time data visualised here shows the number of commits made over time on GitHub during the development of the Kolibri platform.

In Cambodia, an alarming number of children are orphaned or abandoned, left to grow up in residential care facilities, apart from anyone they’ve known.To ensure standards of care are met and children are less exposed to risks in residential care facilities, UNICEF supports the Ministry of Social Affairs, Veterans and Youth to improve the inspection process of these institutions. The existing paper-based process is complicated and long. No real-time feedback loop is currently available to provide results on site to institutions. The Innovation Fund is investing in a new solution to simplify and convert the paper based inspection to a digital form by using a tablet and Open Data Kit software. The initial testing has already shown that the app can complete  the equivalent of a 20-page form — a process that previously took multiple days — in just half a day. The  digital inspection system is being rolled out in five provinces in the first quarter of 2017.

The real-time data visualised here shows the number of commits made over time on GitHub during the adapting of the Open Data Kit software and database to the needs of this project.

Syria is the first country to pilot the U-Report app and engage young people through this new channel. U-Report, launched in Syria on 1 of January, 2017, will play an important role in engaging young people and communities in an emergency context, by collecting data on behaviour change and effectiveness of programmes related to various issues. Priority areas include an increase in immunisation rates, enhancing school enrollment among internally displaced children and increasing the number of children accessing child-friendly spaces. During the project, the global U-Report app was localized to be compatible in Syria. 

The real-time data visualised here shows the number of commits made over time on GitHub during the development of the U-Report App, as well as the growth in number of users of U-Report Syria over time.

U-Report Brazil supports the collection of real-time data from young people and provides them with critical information. The priority issues that U-Report engages young people on include collecting data on the effects of the Zika virus on communities and to disseminating information on prevention practices. U-Report is also used to ensure that young people are involved in the development of the new national base curriculum. In the first stage the polls have addressed issues such as the Zika virus, LGBT rights, HIV Test, violence against girls, sexting, school exclusion, the Olympics and elections - feeding into UNICEF Brasil’s work around these issues. Based on learnings from real-time analytics, the project team has iterated from using SMS as a main channel to reach young people to tapping into newly established Facebook Messenger integration for U-Report - which has led to higher number of users as well as steady response rates.

The real-time data visualized here shows the growth in number of users of U-Report Brazil over time.

U-report, launched in March 2016 in Burkina Faso with the Ministry of Youth, has strengthened young Burkinabé’s participation in themes such as  empowering girls and women to cope with harmful traditional practices, improve key familial practices, safe pregnancy, and good maternal and newborn health. For example, real-time data indicates that school pupils would not take HIV test at school even if the service was provided. This points towards the need of further adapting services (health, social participation) to youth and adolescent needs. Another poll on female genital mutilation indicates that social norms are present among young people and some of the youth are willing to perpetuate that practice. This has helped UNICEF and partners to pinpoint areas in which sensitization efforts are needed. 

The real-time data visualized here shows the growth in number of users of U-Report Burkina Faso over time.

U-Report Guatemala, launched in September 2016, will serve as the main platform for adolescents to link on-going advocacy activities at local level with national policies, including on issues around child marriage, adolescent pregnancy and sexual violence against girls. The data gathered so far shows that more than half of the youth don’t know about a national plan of prevention of adolescent pregnancy - a result which has been shared with the coordinating institutions of this plan. Also, the polls indicate limited opportunities for adolescent participation at local level and insufficient quality of local health services for youth.

The real-time data visualized here shows the growth in number of users of U-Report Guatemala over time.

Category 5 Tropical Cyclone Winston was the strongest to ever hit Fiji, causing widespread damage in all four divisions. UNICEF’s Pacific multi-country office is working with the Government of Fiji to pilot the open source communication platform RapidPro as the foundations of a data collection and feedback mechanism for disaster risk reduction. This platform is currently in its development stages and uses SMS, Facebook and other social messaging platforms to facilitate communications between  key partners involved in disaster preparedness, response, and recovery operations. Within the first week of signing up, 200+ youth have been registered. The next targets are to enroll 1000 youth and 350 youth clubs in collaboration with the Ministry of Youth and Sports.
UNICEF Indonesia organised a challenge with local university partners to engage students to develop solutions for challenges facing children in Indonesia.

UNICEF China has been building out an Innovation Labs in partnership with Tsinghua University. The Lab brought together young entrepreneurs to develop open source technology solutions through a Youth Innovation Forum.
Point-of-care Diagnostics for Women and Children

Currently available diagnostic tests are often not accessible, not widely available or require long waiting periods.Taking a different approach from traditional diagnostic tests, this project identifies biosensors to create rapid tests that do not need lab processing. The remote point-of-care diagnostic will deliver results in 20 minutes, meaning mothers and children can begin effective treatment immediately. At the end of 2016, the HIV sensor is being tested in a cellular environment, pregnancy status biosensor research has begun and the research team is exploring biosensors for malaria well as the dipstick and the digitization process to analyse and provide the results. UNICEF’s Global Innovation Centre continues to support the project financially and through establishing private and academic partnerships.

Myanmar is undergoing transition at a tremendous pace. Changes are demanding new and different ways of thinking and doing things while presenting a unique opportunity to cultivate the skills and experiences required to successfully engage in this new context. For UNICEF, this changing context meant new opportunities and challenges to meaningfully engage young people as active citizens. One step in addressing this challenge was to embark on the establishment of the Myanmar Social Innovation Lab. The Lab, the first of its kind in Myanmar, brings together a number of partners with a focus on research, outreach and training, and solution design.

U-Report is an online portal that allows young people to register and engage from countries where national U-Report initiatives do not exist. Through this additional online architecture, young people can now join from anywhere and speak out on issues that cross borders. The platform has been live since late June 2015 and also acts as a portal for all national U-Report platforms, helping to extend their reach and impact. The data shows the number of registered users on the U-Report platform globally.

U-Report is a mobile phone, text based service designed to give young people a chance to voice their opinions on issues that they care about in their communities and encourage citizen-led development!

U-Report is a mobile-based system that allows young people to speak out on issues that matter to them. In addition to voice amplification, U-Report fills the significant need for real-time information that can be used to strengthen essential service delivery and hold government and development partners accountable. U-Report was launched in Burundi in early 2014 and users are engaged in regular reporting within their communities. With support from the Innovation Fund, eight province-level multi-partner teams have been established and trained in U-Report and project planning. These teams will mobilise U-Report engagement at province level including through coordination and delivery of public launch activities. The data shows the number of users in Burundi who are currently registered to use U-Report.

UNICEF Chile is rolling out U-Report through Twitter and SMS to engage young people in a range of key issues. In its first phase, issues prioritised by young people themselves are addressed -including sexual and reproductive health and teen suicide. Eventually U-Report will be used to engage young people in national policy development processes, linked to for instance the Constitution and the new Law on Education. U-Report Chile is positioned in partnership with The Ministry of Health, the National Youth Institute as well as local civil society organisations.

Mexico was the first country to launch U-Report in Latin America. UNICEF Mexico launched the first digital version of U-Report in partnership with The Mexican Youth Institute. SMS will be introduced at a later date, but the platform has been operated over Twitter (@UreportMexico).

A tripartite partnership between Digicel Foundation, UNICEF Papua New Guinea and the National Department of Health (NDoH) is contributing towards the target of elimination of new HIV infections among children by 2015. Using RapidPro, this pilot project aimed to increase the number of women and children living with HIV who receive treatment and care; reduce loss to follow-up; improve referrals to maternal and child health services and those related to prevention of parent to child transmission; strengthen ante-natal care for all pregnant women and support supply chain management.

UNICEF Innovation explored whether Vojo is suitable to support youth participatory initiatives in South Africa, and  what changes would need to be made to the technology in order to improve its relevance in a South African youth context. Vojo is a mobile-phone based storytelling application that allows users from all over the world to share and post stories about their lives, situations, challenges and triumphs through voice messages, SMS and MMS. It can also be used via landline phone for those who do not have access to a mobile phone. The pilot's finding confirmed that Vojo had the potential as a tool to increase youth engagement through an additional channel, provided adaptations were made to suit the context and specific needs of young people
Yuudee App for Children with Autism

Yuudee is an augmentative and alternative communication tool for children who have difficulty in speech and can also be used as a teaching tool for parents and teachers to teach children communication and cognitive skills. Children can press an icon and the App will “speak” out a short sentence or phrase that expresses a need, request, emotion or answer. A built-in repository of more than 400 icons is available for users as a start. Parents and teachers can easily add to these resources and customize lessons catering to the specific needs of each child, with flexible and user-friendly customization functions supported by Yuudee. Development of the Android version and translation of the app into English will be completed to facilitate future scale-up.

In Namibia, geographic, social and economic inequities cause  disparities in learning outcomes. UNICEF Namibia is improving access to quality education with 2 technological tools: An eLearning portal “Do Like EDU” that  will support learner performance in key subject areas, and the “Talk to Edu” mobile app that  will provide learners with psychosocial support and career guidance. These tools are an adapted version of a South African eLearning platform called LevelUp which has received positive feedback and attracted a large  number of active users. The platform deploys a point-reward system which motivates learners and ensures high retention rates. During the project, UNICEF Namibia will  bring together the most suitable existing eLearning and mobile learning initiatives in Namibia’s tech ecosystem and map them onto the Namibian curriculum. With the investment, the Namibian platform will also be made open source.
